Neuroscientist exposes ineffectiveness of flu vaccines: https://newslog.cyberjournal.org/neuroscientist-chris-shaw-slams-h1n1-vaccines/
List of studies from 1981 to 2015 on the ineffectiveness of face masks to prevent infection: Neil Orr’s study, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2493952/pdf/annrcse01509-0009.pdf published in 1981 in the Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. Dr. Orr was a surgeon in the Severalls Surgical Unit in Colchester. And for six months, from March through August 1980, the
surgical staff in that unit decided to see what would happen if they did
not wear masks during surgeries. They wore no masks for six months, and
compared the rate of surgical wound infections from March through
August 1980 with the rate of wound infections from March through August
of the previous four years. And they discovered, to their amazement,
that when nobody wore masks during surgeries, the rate of wound
infections was less than half what it was when everyone wore masks.
Conclusion: “It would appear that minimum contamination can best be
achieved by not wearing a mask at all” and that wearing a mask during
surgery “is a standard procedure that could be abandoned.”

Masks are useless in preventing the spread of disease and, if anything,
are unsanitary objects that themselves spread bacteria and viruses.
Masks get touched regularly, sneezed in, coughed in, and hold moisture
thus creating unnecessary contamination.

In Tunevall’s 1991 study,
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01658736 a general surgical
team wore no masks in half of their surgeries for two years. After 1,537
operations performed with masks, the wound infection rate was 4.7%,
while after 1,551 operations performed without masks, the wound
infection rate was only 3.5%.

A review by Skinner and Sutton in 2001
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0310057X0102900402
concluded that “The evidence for discontinuing the use of surgical face
masks would appear to be stronger than the evidence available to support
their continued use.”

Lahme et al., in 2001, https://europepmc.org/article/med/11760479 wrote
that “surgical face masks worn by patients during regional anaesthesia,
did not reduce the concentration of airborne bacteria over the operation
field in our study.”

Figueiredo et al., in 2001,
http://www.advancesinpd.com/adv01/21Figueiredo.htm reported that in five
years of doing peritoneal dialysis without masks, rates of peritonitis
in their unit were no different.

Vaccine development is good, but nobody talks about the development of better PPE.
It is perfectly possible to design and manufacture PPE ( personal protective equipment ) that is reusable and disinfectable.
A vaccine is only useful to one kind of virus, while PPE is effective to ALL kinds of viruses.
There will be other pandemics by other kinds of viruses and the current vaccines will be useless.
Creating a new vaccine for a new kind of virus takes a long time.

Instead of a vaccine, it is much more effective to develop better PPE.
PPE needs to be reusable, washable, disinfectable and widely available to the general population.
There is no reason for PPE to be disposable.
On one hand you say you can kill the virus with soap and water, but you cannot disinfect PPE?? How is that even possible??

The only reason PPE is disposable is that it is more profitable for manufacturers.
Hospitals need to constantly keep buying PPE, and making the manufacturers richer.
I understand that it is much more convenient for hospitals to simply throw away PPE than trying to disinfect it.
The only problem is when there is a major epidemic.

And the general population also needs PPE.
It is not difficult to design and manufacture a simple mask made of hard plastic that covers the nose and mouth, that is reusable and rewashable with soap or disinfectant.
The filter for such a mask does not need to be N95 level, because it is designed for the general population. The filter could be something as simple as toilet paper. Only the filter should be disposed and replaced regularly.

Private companies have no incentive to develop reusable PPE because they are not profitable.
So governments need to take the initiative to promote the research and development of reusable PPE.
